properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today and tonight. Travel will be hazardous due to a quick accumulation of snow, especially this afternoon, with near 10 centimetres expected by later this evening. Blowing snow across the region will continue until later this evening and possibly into Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T10:29:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-29T18:30:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1642625950.2019
Area: Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson, Dryden - Vermilion Bay, Ignace - English River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain continuing tonight into Monday. Freezing rain is expected to continue tonight into Monday morning. Temperatures are expected to remain near the freezing mark resulting in precipitation falling as freezing rain or rain. The freezing rain is expected to change to rain Monday afternoon. In addition, strong wind gusts of 60 to 70 km/h will affect the area into Monday. Ice accretion or build-up of 5 to 10 mm is possible and combined with the strong wind gusts, widespread power outages are possible. Travel is expected to be very poor today into Monday, especially inland and over higher terrain where colder temperatures will result in more ice build-up on untreated surfaces. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T13:24:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-29T21:25:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1786764621.2019
Area: Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and rain expected New Year's Eve into New Year's Day. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Locally higher amounts possible. Total rainfall: 5 to 15 mm. Locations: All of New Brunswick for snow, mainly southern New Brunswick for rain. Time span: Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning, persisting into Wednesday afternoon over northern New Brunswick. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Snow is expected to develop Tuesday morning ahead of this system and spread to all of the province by late Tuesday afternoon. Snow will gradually change to possibly a brief period of freezing rain or ice pellets and then to rain over southern and eastern New Brunswick Tuesday night into Wednesday morning, but should persist as snow over northwestern sections well into Wednesday. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation could impact those travelling on New Year's Eve or New Year's Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T11:50:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-29T19:51:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4067680923.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and strong winds expected on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Locally higher amounts possible. Total rainfall: 5 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 90 km/h, possibly higher. Locations: Iles-de-la-Madeleine Time span: Late Tuesday evening into Wednesday morning. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Snow is expected to develop Tuesday evening ahead of this system and potentially become heavy at times before changing to rain overnight then ending Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting up to 80 km/h or higher will develop Tuesday evening then diminish Wednesday morning. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact those travelling on New Year's Eve or early on New Year's Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T11:56:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-29T19:57:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1241498740.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow are expected locally on Tuesday and Wednesday ... An intense low pressure system will reach New England Tuesday evening bringing snow and blowing snow over Central and Eastern Quebec. Snowfall amounts are expected to exceed 15 centimetres in all areas and could even approach 30 centimetres over the eastern tip of the Gaspé Peninsula. With those winter conditions, road conditions should deteriorate. Consider the possibility of modifying non-essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T12:25:15-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mix of wintry weather including freezing rain expected through Monday. Precipitation across the region including snow, ice pellets and some freezing rain near Wawa will transition to mainly ice pellets or freezing rain tonight. Precipitation will intensify again Monday morning. There will again be a transition to snow Monday afternoon. Ice accretion or build-up of up to 10 mm is possible. Untreated surfaces may become slippery and power outages are possible. Travel conditions will continue to deteriorate this evening and continue to be hazardous through Monday night. ### Road closures are possible. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Locations: All of Prince Edward Island. Time span: Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday morning. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Snow is expected to develop Tuesday afternoon ahead of this system and potentially become heavy at times before a possible brief changeover to freezing rain or ice pellets and then to rain near midnight before ending Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting up to 70 km/h or higher will develop Tuesday evening then diminish Wednesday morning. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact those travelling during New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and strong winds expected New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 2 cm in the southwest to 10 cm in the north, possibly higher over the Cape Breton Highlands. Total rainfall: 10 to 30 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h, higher in Les Suetes. Locations: All of Nova Scotia. Time span: Near Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning. Remarks: A disturbance is expected to develop near Cape Cod early on New Year's Eve and track slowly northeastward across New Brunswick on New Year's Day. Rain or snow is expected to develop Tuesday morning over southwestern Nova Scotia ahead of this system and then spread to all regions of the province by Tuesday evening. There may be a brief period of ice pellets or freezing rain before the changeover to rain. Strong southeast winds gusting up to 80 km/h or possibly higher will develop Tuesday afternoon and evening then diminish overnight. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation and strong winds could impact those travelling on New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions with wind chill values near minus 50 are forecast to end later tonight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T09:39:05-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain or ice pellets expected to develop tonight. Snow is expected to change to ice pellets or freezing rain this evening and transition back to snow Monday morning. There is still uncertainty regarding the dominant precipitation type, however travel is expected to be hazardous at times tonight and Monday morning particularly areas near Highway 129. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T13:04:58-00:00

Area: Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets and risk of freezing rain expected. A significant mix of wintry precipitation is expected over much of Northern Ontario tonight into Monday, including snow, ice pellets and a risk of freezing rain. Total snow and ice pellet amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible by Monday evening. Additionally, strong easterly winds may accompany the precipitation, particularly on Monday. Travel conditions are expected to deteriorate through tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T13:34:53-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy ending this evening. There will be additional snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 centimetres this evening. Local blowing snow may also make travel difficult early this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A storm will track across the northern interior of British Columbia late Monday bringing heavy snow to Pine Pass and Williston. Snow will begin near noon Monday. Snow will taper off and become mixed with rain overnight Monday night. We expect a total of 10 to 15 cm of snow between noon Monday and early Tuesday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T16:00:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T00:01:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3914383739.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values near -55 tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-30T12:32:05-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain or ice pellets expected to develop early Monday. Ice pellets and snow are expected to begin this evening. Ice pellets will then become the main precipitation type overnight, and later become mixed with freezing rain by Monday morning. There is still uncertainty regarding the dominant precipitation type, however travel is expected to be hazardous at times tonight and Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery.
